text:
> I couldn't figure out how you could have 3 interacting things colliding in a markov chain, but it sounds like the answer is: you can't. That isn't have enzymes work.
It's a chemical kinetic property that makes 3 interacting things very unlikely, but there's nothing about Markov chains that prevents this.

You can have states as you wish in a Markov Chain, and define transition probabilities according to your wishes.

e.g. you could represent the reaction A + B + C -> D
with a reaction rate proportional to [#A][#B][#C], and this would all be legitimate mathematics.

This stuff does happen in some models quite frequently (even if it's unrealistic from a chemical kinetic standpoint). For example, I'm sure you can find multiple Gillespie simulations of the Brusselator with a bit of Googling.

text: <@U7Z4938R3> Many models use trimolecular reactions, `A+B+C --> D` in Catalyst.jl notation, particularly for toy pattern formation examples (where there is spatial transport too). So while they aren't so physical, and it is more correct to break them into multiple bimolecular reactions as you wrote, they do get used a decent amount in the literature. You can generate all the different model versions (ODE, SDE and jumps) through Catalyst on top of ModelingToolkit if you want to play around.
